The candidate then put off his garments and entered the baptistery. 'He was immediately anointed,2 from head to foot, with exorcised oil. In the case of the women, this anointing was performed by deaconesses.

After this anointing‚ the neophyte entered the font, which had been previously blessed by the bishop.3 He once more confessed his faith, replying to the threefold questioning of the officiating minister, and was then plunged three times in the consecrated water.

Having quitted the font, the candidate4 was anointed

with perfumed unguents (μύρου, chrism). According 130 St. Cyril’s account, this was administered on the forehead, ears, nose, and breast. He then turned to the east and recited the Lord's Prayer.⁵ The ceremony ended with the celebration of the Eucharist, in which the neophytes took part for the first time. In the countries which followed the Alexandrian use, the first communion was followed by the reception of the draught of milk and honey‚ as at Rome. 6
